title: Streaming problems as (multi-issue) claims problems

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We study the problem of allocating the revenues raised via paid subscriptions to music streaming platforms among participating artists. We show that the main methods to solve streaming problems (pro-rata, user-centric and families generalizing them) can be seen as specific (well-known) rules to solve (multi-issue) claims problems. Our results permit to provide strong links between the well-established literature on claims problems and the emerging literature on streaming problems.


JEL numbers: D63, C71, L82, O34.
Keywords: Streaming, revenue allocation, multi-issue claims problems, pro-rata, user-centric.

# 1 Introduction 

The problem of adjudicating conflicting claims (in short, claims problem) models a basic situation in which an endowment is allocated among agents who have claims on it, and the available amount is not enough to fully honor all claims. This is a classic problem that can be traced back to ancient sources, such as Aristotle and the Talmud, although its formal treatment is somewhat recent (e.g., O’Neill, 1982). A sizable literature at the intersection of economics and operations research emerged afterwards (see, for instance, Thomson (2019) and the literature cited therein). Some of the efforts within that literature have been devoted to generalize claims problems to account for multiple issues (e.g., Calleja et al., 2005; Ju et al., 2007). ${ }^{1}$

From a different vantage point, there has been a growing interest in recent years to analyze platform businesses, which have transformed the ways in which cultural content is produced and consumed (e.g., Aguiar et al., 2024). This is particularly the case with music. According to Statista, in the third quarter of 2024, Spotify (the largest music streaming platform) reached an all-time high with 640 million active users worldwide. The problem of sharing the revenue raised from paid subscriptions to streaming platforms among artists, a new form of revenue sharing problems under bundled pricing (e.g., Adams and Yellen, 1976; Ginsburgh and Zang, 2003; Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2015, 2016) is of critical importance to understand the management of music platforms. We show in this paper that such a problem can actually be approached resorting to the literature on (multi-issue) claims problems mentioned above.

Traditionally, music platforms used a pro-rata method to award artists based on the relative number of total streamings they achieved in the platform. Gradually, they have been moving to a decentralized method in which the amount paid by each user is allocated among the artists that user streamed. If the latter allocation is proportional to individual streamings, we obtain the so-called user-centric method. If, instead, the allocation does not distinguish among artists that were streamed, we obtain the so-called Shapley method. Varying the allocation method, we obtain the family of probabilistic methods (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2025). And compromising between the pro-rata and user-centric methods we obtain the family of weighted methods (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2025).

We show in this paper that all the methods described above can actually be derived from existing rules to solve (multi-issue) claims problems. Key among the latter are the so-called two-

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Acosta et al., $(2022,2023)$ have recently extended this multidimensional setting to allow for crossed claims.

stage rules, which first divide the endowment among issues, and then divide the amount assigned to each issue among the agents. More precisely, we show that the family of probabilistic indices induces the same rewards as the family of two-stage rules where we use the classical constrained equal awards rule in the first stage, and any claims rule (satisfying two basic requirements) for the second stage. Similarly, we show that the family of user-weighted indices induces the same rewards as the family of two-stage rules where we use the classical proportional rule in the second stage, and any claims rule (satisfying a basic requirement) for the first stage.

Our work can thus be interpreted as providing extension operators to convert rules to solve claims problems into rules to solve streaming problems. As such, we align with the literature dealing with operators on the space of claims rules (e.g., Thomson and Yeh, 2008; Hougaard et al., 2012; 2013a; 2013b; Moreno-Ternero and Vidal-Puga, 2021). We also align with the literature that applies the well-established framework from claims problems to solve various related allocation problems with real-life implications. Recent instances are water conflicts (e.g., Mianabadi et al., 2014), linguistic subsidies (e.g., Ginsburgh and Moreno-Ternero, 2018), broadcasting problems (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2020), $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ emissions (e.g., Duro et al., 2020), slots allocation in sport competitions (e.g., Krumer and Moreno-Ternero, 2020), or pollution abatement (e.g., Ju et al., 2021).

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce the basic aspects of claims problems. In Section 3, we introduce the basic aspects of streaming problems. In Section 4, we provide the bridge between both types of problems, as well as our main results. We conclude in Section 5.

# 2 Claims problems 

Claims problems refer to an amount of a homogeneous and infinitely divisible good (e.g., money) to be divided among a set of agents, who have claims on the good that cannot be fully honored. See, for instance, Thomson (2019) for an excellent recent survey on the topic. A well-known example is bankruptcy. But many others can also fit this framework. Formally, a claims problem is a triple $(N, c, E)$ where $N$ is the set of agents, $c \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{N}$ is the claims vector and $E \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$is the amount to be divided. It is assumed that $\sum_{i \in N} c_{i} \geq E$. Let $\mathcal{C}$ denote the set of claims problems.

A (claims) rule is a function $R$ assigning to each claims problem $(N, c, E) \in \mathcal{C}$ a vector $R(N, c, E) \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$ such that $\sum_{i \in N} R_{i}(N, c, E)=E$.

Some examples of well-known rules are presented next.
The constrained equal awards rule equalizes the amount received by each agent as much as possible, subject to the constraint that no agent gets an amount above his claim. Formally, for each $(N, c, E) \in \mathcal{C}$, and each $i \in N$,

$$
C E A_{i}(N, c, E)=\min \left\{\lambda, c_{i}\right\}
$$

where $\lambda$ satisfies $\sum_{i \in N} \min \left\{\lambda, c_{i}\right\}=E$.
The proportional rule yields awards proportionally to claims. Formally, for each $(N, c, E) \in$ $\mathcal{C}$, and each $i \in N$,

$$
P_{i}(N, c, E)=\frac{c_{i}}{\sum_{j \in N} c_{j}} E
$$

The weighted proportional rule yields awards proportionally to weighted claims. Formally, given weights $\left(w_{i}\right)_{i \in N}$, for each $(N, c, E) \in \mathcal{C}$ and each $i \in N$,

$$
P_{i}^{w}(N, c, E)=\frac{w_{i} c_{i}}{\sum_{j \in N} w_{j} c_{j}} E
$$

A multi-issue claims problem (e.g., Ju et al., 2007) is a tuple $(N, K, c, E)$ where $N$ is a set of agents, $K$ is a set of issues, $c=\left(c_{i j}\right)_{i \in N, j \in K}$ where for all $i \in N$ and $j \in K, c_{i j} \geq 0$ denotes the characteristic of agent $i$ on issue $j$, and $E \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$is the amount of a homogeneous and infinitely divisible good to be divided. ${ }^{2}$ Let $\mathcal{M C}$ denote the set of multi-issue claims problems. For each $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ and each $j \in K$, let $c_{. j}=\left(c_{i j}\right)_{i \in N}$ and $C^{j}=\sum_{i \in N} c_{i j}$.

A (multi-issue claims) rule is a function $R$ assigning to each multi-issue claims problem $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ a vector $R(N, K, c, E) \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$.

A well-known family of rules is defined as follows. First, a weight function is a function $\omega$ : $\mathbb{R}_{+}^{K} \times \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{+}^{K}$, which assigns a probability distribution $\omega(x, y)$; namely, $0 \leq w_{j}(x, y) \leq 1$ for all $j \in K$ and $\sum_{j \in K} w_{j}(x, y)=1$. The (multi-issue) weighted proportional rule associated with $w: \mathbb{R}_{++}^{K} \times \mathbb{R}_{++} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{K}$ assigns for each problem $(N, K, c, E)$ and each $i \in N$,

$$
P_{i}^{w}(N, K, c, E)=\sum_{j \in K} \frac{c_{i j}}{C^{j}} \omega_{j}\left(\left(C^{j}\right)_{j \in K}, E\right) E
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ Calleja et al. (2005) introduce multi-issue allocation situations, which are a particular case of multi-issue claims problems.

Alternatively, the literature has also considered two-stage rules, where in the first stage the endowment is divided among the issues, and in the second stage the amount assigned to each issue is divided among the agents. The final amount received by each agent is the sum over all issues. Formally, let $\psi$ and $\left\{\phi^{j}\right\}_{j \in K}$ be some claims rules. The two-stage rule $R^{\psi, \phi}$ is the rule obtained from the following two-stage procedure:

1. First stage. We consider the claims problem among the issues $\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)$, where $c^{K}=$ $\left(c_{j}^{K}\right)_{j \in K}$ and for each $j \in K, c_{j}^{K}=\sum_{i \in N} c_{i j}$. We compute $\psi\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)$.
2. Second stage. For each $j \in K$, we consider the claims problem $\left(N, c_{. j}, \psi_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)$. We compute $\phi^{j}\left(N, c_{. j}, \psi_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)$.

For each $i \in N$ we define,

$$
R_{i}^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, C, E)=\sum_{j \in K} \phi_{i}^{j}\left(N, c_{. j}, \psi_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)
$$

Moreno-Ternero (2009) and Bergantiños et al. (2010) study the two-stage rule where the proportional rule is used in both stages (namely, $\psi=\phi^{j}=P$ for all $j \in K$ ). ${ }^{3}$ Lorenzo-Freire et al. (2010) and Bergantiños et al. (2011) study the two-stage rule where the constrained equal awards rule is used in both stages (namely, $\psi=\phi^{j}=C E A$ for all $j \in K$ ). Bergantiños et al. (2018) study the two-stage rule where the constrained equal awards rule is used in the first stage and the proportional rule in the second stage (namely, $\psi=C E A$ and $\phi^{j}=P$ for all $j \in K)$.

# 3 Streaming problems 

We now consider streaming problems, as introduced by Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero (2025). Let $\mathbb{N}$ represent the set of all potential artists and $\mathbb{M}$ the set of all potential users (of music streaming platforms). We can assume, without loss of generality, that both $\mathbb{N}$ and $\mathbb{M}$ are sufficiently large. In particular, we assume that $|\mathbb{M}| \geq 3$. Each specific platform involves a specific (finite) set of artists $N \subset \mathbb{N}$ and a specific (finite) set of users $M \subset \mathbb{M}$, with cardinalities $n$ and $m$, respectively. For ease of notation, we typically assume that $N=\{1, \ldots, n\}$ and $M=\{1, \ldots, m\}$. For each pair $i \in N, j \in M$, let $t_{i j}$ denote the times user $j$ played (via

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ See also Mármol and Hinojosa (2020).

streaming) contents uploaded by artist $i$ in a platform (briefly, streams), during a certain period of time (e.g., month). In most of the platforms, playing a streaming unit will be equivalent to playing a song (for at least 30 seconds). Let $t=\left(t_{i j}\right)_{i \in N, j \in M}$ denote the corresponding matrix encompassing all streams. We assume that for each $j \in M, \sum_{i \in N} t_{i j}>0$ (namely, each user has streamed some content).

A streaming problem is a triple $P=(N, M, t)$. Following Bergantiños and MorenoTernero (2025), we normalize the amount paid by each user to 1 . Thus, the amount to be divided among artists in a problem $(N, M, t)$ is just $m$, the number of users. The set of problems so defined is denoted by $\mathcal{P}$.

For each $j \in M$, we denote by $t^{-j}$ the matrix obtained from $t$ by removing the column corresponding to user $j$. For each artist $i \in N, T_{i}(N, M, t)=\sum_{j \in M} t_{i j}$, denotes the total times $i$ was streamed. Likewise, for each user $j \in M, T^{j}(N, M, t)=\sum_{i \in N} t_{i j}$, denotes the total times $j$ streamed content. Notice that, by assumption, $T^{j}(N, M, t)>0$.

We define the set of fans of each artist as the set of users who have streamed content from the artist at least once. Formally, for each $i \in N, F_{i}(N, M, t)=\left\{j \in M: t_{i j}>0\right\}$. Similarly, we define the list of artists of a user as those from which the user has streamed content at least once. Formally, for each $j \in M, L^{j}(N, M, t)=\left\{i \in N: t_{i j}>0\right\}$. The profile of user $j$ is defined as the streaming vector associated to such a user. Namely, $t_{. j}(N, M, t)=\left(t_{i j}\right)_{i \in N}$. When no confusion arises we write $T_{i}$ instead of $T_{i}(N, M, t), T^{j}$ instead of $T^{j}(N, M, t), F_{i}$ instead of $F_{i}(N, M, t), L^{j}$ instead of $L^{j}(N, M, t)$, and $t_{. j}$ instead of $t_{. j}(N, M, t)$.

A popularity index for streaming problems is a mapping that measures the importance of each artist in each problem. Formally, for each problem $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}, I(N, M, t) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n}$ and, for each pair $i, j \in N, I_{i}(N, M, t) \geq I_{j}(N, M, t)$ if and only if $i$ is at least as important as $j$ at problem $(N, M, t)$. We assume that $\sum_{i \in N} I_{i}(N, M, t)>0$.

The reward received by each artist $i \in N$ from the revenues generated in each problem ( $m$ because the amount paid by each user has been normalized to 1 ) is based on the importance of that artist in that problem. Formally,

$$
R_{i}^{I}(N, M, t)=\frac{I_{i}(N, M, t)}{\sum_{k \in N} I_{k}(N, M, t)} m
$$

Note that any positive linear transformation of a given index generates the same allocation of rewards. Formally, for each $\lambda>0$ and each index $I, R^{\lambda I} \equiv R^{I}$. Thus, unless stated otherwise,

we shall slightly abuse language to identify an index with all its positive linear transformations.
The index used by most platforms is the so-called pro-rata index, which simply measures importance by the total number of streams. Formally, for each problem $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ and each artist $i \in N$,

$$
P_{i}(N, M, t)=T_{i}=\sum_{j \in M} t_{i j}
$$

Thus, the amount received by each artist $i \in N$ under $P$ is

$$
R_{i}^{P}(N, M, t)=\frac{T_{i}}{\sum_{k \in N} T_{k}} m
$$

Another index used in some platforms is the so-called user-centric index. The amount paid by each user is divided among the artists streamed by the user, proportionally to the total number of streams. Then, the index assigns each artist the sum of the amounts obtained across users. Formally, for each problem $(N, M, t)$ and each artist $i \in N$,

$$
U_{i}(N, M, t)=\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}}
$$

It is easy to see that $R^{U}(N, M, t)=U(N, M, t)$.
The above two indices have been largely studied, for instance, in Alaei et al., (2022), Meyn et al. (2023), Gonçalves-Dosantos et al., $(2024,2025)$ and Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero (2025).

We also consider the Shapley index, studied in Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero (2024) and Gonçalves-Dosantos et al., (2024). ${ }^{4}$ Formally, for each $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ and each $i \in N$,

$$
S h_{i}(N, M, t)=\sum_{j \in M} \sum_{i \in L^{j}} \frac{1}{\left|L^{j}\right|}
$$

Thus, under the Shapley index the subscription of each user $j$ is equally allocated among the artists $j$ streamed. As in the case of user-centric, the amount received by each artist from this index is precisely just what the index indicates. Namely,

$$
R^{S h}(N, M, t)=S h(N, M, t)
$$

We compare the three indices in the following example.

t=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
10 & 0 \\
20 & 0 \\
0 & 70

$$

We then have the following:

A weight system is a function $\omega: \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that for each $j \in \mathbb{M}$ and each $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}$, $\omega(j, x)>0$. For each weight system $\omega$, its weighted index $I^{\omega}$ is defined so that for each $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ and each $i \in N$,

$$
I_{i}^{\omega}(N, M, t)=\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i j}
$$

The value the index yields for each artist is obtained as the sum, over all users, of the streams of the user-weighteded by a factor that depends on the user and the streaming profile of the user. Both pro-rata and user-centric are weighted indices. However, the Shapley index is not a weighted index (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2024; 2025).

A probability system is a function $\rho: \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}$ such that for each $j \in \mathbb{M}$ and each $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}, 0 \leq \rho_{i}(j, x) \leq 1, \rho_{i}(j, x)=0$ when $x_{i}=0$, and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{i}(j, x)=1$. For each probability system $\rho$, its probabilistic index $I^{\rho}$ is defined so that for each $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ and each $i \in N$,

$$
I_{i}^{\rho}(N, M, t)=\sum_{j \in M} \rho_{i}\left(j, t_{. j}\right)
$$

Then, the subscription of each user $j$ is fully allocated among the artists $j$ streamed (those that $j$ did not play get nothing) in an arbitrary way that depends on $j$ 's streaming vector. Both the user-centric and the Shapley indices are probabilistic. However, the pro-rata index is not (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2024; 2025).

# 4 A bridge between claims and streaming problems 

We could first associate with each streaming problem $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ a claims problem in a trivial way. To wit, let the (overall) amount paid by users be the amount to be divided. And let the claim of each artist be its number of streams. Formally, we consider

$$
(N, c(N, M, t), E(N, M, t)) \in \mathcal{C}
$$

where, for each $i \in N, c_{i}(N, M, t)=T_{i}$, and $E(N, M, t)=m$. As no (streaming) rule depending on $t_{i j}$ can be computed in this way, we associate instead with each streaming problem $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ a multi-issue claims problem. Namely,

$$
(N, K(N, M, t), c(N, M, t), E(N, M, t)) \in \mathcal{M C}
$$

where $K(N, M, t)=M, c(N, M, t)=t$, and $E(N, M, t)=m$. When no confusion arises, we write $(N, K, c, E)$ instead of $(N, K(N, M, t), c(N, M, t), E(N, M, t))$.

Notice that the set of issues is the set of users, the characteristic of agent $i$ on issue $j$ is just the number of streams of user $j$ on artist $i$, and the amount to be divided is the amount paid by the users (which coincides with the number of issues because of the normalization). Thus, the set of (multi-issue) claims problems associated with streaming problems corresponds with the ones where $c_{i j} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}$ for all $i \in N$ and $j \in M$, and $E=|K|$.

With the previous association, two-stage rules have a natural interpretation in streaming problems. In the first stage, we decide the importance of each user in the final allocation (taking into account the total number of streams of each user). We allow, for instance, that more active users have more importance. In the second stage, we decide, for each user, the importance of each artist (taking into account the streams of the user).

### 4.1 Results for individual indices

In our first result, we provide the connections between the three basic indices presented above and claims rules. More precisely, we show that the rewards associated with the pro-rata and user-centric indices belong to the family of multi-issue weigthed proportional rules, whereas this is not the case for the Shapley index. We also show that the rewards associated with the three indices can be seen as two-stage rules associated with the two well-known (unidimensional) claims rules: the proportional rule and the constrained equal awards rule.

Theorem 1 Let $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ be a streaming problem and $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ be the associated (multi-issue) claims problem. Then, the following statements hold:

- There exists a weight function $w^{P}$ such that $R^{P}(N, M, t)=P^{w^{P}}(N, K, c, E)$.
- There exists a weight function $w^{U}$ such that $U(N, M, t)=P^{w^{U}}(N, K, c, E)$.
- There does not exist a weight function $w^{S}$ such that $S(N, M, t)=P^{w^{S}}(N, K, c, E)$.
- $R^{P}(N, M, t)=R^{P, P}(N, K, c, E)$.
- $U(N, M, t)=R^{C E A, P}(N, K, c, E)$.
- $\operatorname{Sh}(N, M, t)=R^{C E A, C E A}(N, K, c, E)$.

Proof. For the first item, we consider $w^{P}: \mathbb{R}_{++}^{K} \times \mathbb{R}_{++} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{K}$ where for each $\left(\left(C^{j^{\prime}}\right)_{j^{\prime} \in K}, E\right)$,

$$
\omega_{j}^{P}\left(\left(C^{j^{\prime}}\right)_{j^{\prime} \in K}, E\right)=\frac{C^{j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in K} C^{j^{\prime}}} \text { for each } j \in M
$$

Then, for each $i \in N$,

$$
P_{i}^{w^{P}}(N, K, c, E)=\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}} \frac{T^{j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in K} T^{j^{\prime}}} m=\frac{\sum_{j \in M} t_{i j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in K} T^{j^{\prime}}} m=\frac{T_{i}}{\sum_{i^{\prime} \in N} T_{i^{\prime}}} m=R_{i}^{P}(N, M, t)
$$

For the second item, we consider $w^{U}: \mathbb{R}_{++}^{K} \times \mathbb{R}_{++} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{K}$ where for each $\left(\left(C^{j^{\prime}}\right)_{j^{\prime} \in K}, E\right)$,

$$
\omega_{j}^{U}\left(\left(C^{j^{\prime}}\right)_{j^{\prime} \in K}, E\right)=\frac{1}{|K|} \text { for each } j \in M
$$

Then, for each $i \in N$,

$$
P_{i}^{w^{U}}(N, K, c, E)=\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}} \frac{1}{m} m=\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}}=U_{i}(N, M, t)
$$

For the third item, we note that each (multi-issue) weighted proportional rule satisfies reallocation-proofnes (e.g., Ju el al., 2007). That is, for each $S \subset N$ such that $\sum_{i \in S} c_{i j}=\sum_{i \in S} c_{i j}^{\prime}$, we have that $\sum_{i \in S} R_{i}(N, K, c, E)=\sum_{i \in S} R_{i}\left(N, K, c^{\prime}, E\right)$. Let $(N, M, t)$ and $\left(N, M, t^{\prime}\right)$ be such that $M=\{j\}$. The associated claims problems are $(N, K, c, E)$ and $\left(N, K, c^{\prime}, E\right)$ where $K=\{j\}$,

$E=1, c=t$ and $c^{\prime}=t^{\prime}$. Assume that $N=\{1,2,3\}, t=(20,0,10), t^{\prime}=(10,10,10)$, and $S=\{1,2\}$. Then,

$$
\sum_{i \in S} S h_{i}(N, M, t)=\frac{1}{2} \text { and } \sum_{i \in S} S h_{i}\left(N, M, t^{\prime}\right)=\frac{2}{3}
$$

Thus, $S h$ does not satisfy reallocation proofness and, hence, it cannot be associated to a (multi-issue) weighted proportional rule.

For the fourth item, let $i \in N$ be given and compute $R_{i}^{P, P}(N, K, c, E)$.
First stage. For each $j \in K$,

$$
P_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)=\frac{T^{j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in K} T^{j^{\prime}}} m
$$

Second stage.

$$
P_{i}\left(N, c_{. j}, P_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=\frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}} \frac{T^{j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in M} T^{j^{\prime}}} m=\frac{t_{i j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in M} T^{j^{\prime}}} m
$$

Thus, for each $i \in N$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{i}^{P, P}(R, N, E, C) & =\sum_{j \in K} P_{i}\left(N, c_{. j}, P_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in M} T^{j^{\prime}}} m=\frac{T_{i}}{\sum_{i^{\prime} \in N} T_{i^{\prime}}} m=R_{i}^{P}(N, M, t)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the fourth item, let $i \in N$ be given and compute $R_{i}^{C E A, P}(N, K, c, E)$.
First stage. For each $j \in K, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)=\min \left\{\lambda, T^{j}\right\}$ where $\sum_{j \in K} \min \left\{\lambda, T^{j}\right\}=E$. It is straightforward to check that $\lambda=1$. Hence, $C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)=1$.

Second stage.

$$
P_{i}\left(N, c_{. j}, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=\frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}}
$$

Thus, for each $i \in N$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{i}^{C E A, P}(R, N, E, C) & =\sum_{j \in K} P_{i}\left(N, c_{. j}, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}}=U_{i}(N, M, t)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the sixth item, let $i \in N$ be given and compute $R_{i}^{C E A, C E A}(N, K, c, E)$.

First stage. Similarly to the previous item, we obtain that, for each $j \in K, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)=$ 1 .

Second stage.

$$
C E A_{i}\left(N, c_{. j}, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{1}{\left|L^{j}\right|} & \text { if } i \in L^{j} \\
0 & \text { otherwise }
\end{array} .\right.
$$

Thus, for each $i \in N$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{i}^{C E A, C E A}(R, N, E, C) & =\sum_{j \in K} C E A_{i}\left(N, c_{. j}, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)) \\
& =\sum_{j \in M} \sum_{i \in L^{j}} \frac{1}{\left|L^{j}\right|}=S h_{i}(N, M, t)
\end{aligned}
$$

The last three items of Theorem 1 allow us to consider the three indices from a different perspective. The allocation rules they induce (for streaming problems) can actually be described as two-stage (claim) rules where we first decide the importance of each user and then the importance of each artist for each user. The user-centric and Shapley indices measure the importance of all users equally (applying the $C E A$ rule) whereas pro-rata measures the importance of each user proportionally to the number of streams (applying the proportional rule). To measure the importance of each artist for each user, pro-rata and user-centric do it proportionally to the artists' streams (applying the proportional rule), whereas the Shapley index states that all artists streamed by the user have the same importance (applying the $C E A$ rule).

Theorem 1 considers three possible two-stage rules arising from combining the $C E A$ and $P$ rules in different ways. The other combination between these two rules that is not captured in Theorem 1 is $R^{P, C E A}$, which we now illustrate. Let $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ be a streaming problem and $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ be the associated (multi-issue) claims problem. For each $i \in N$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{i}^{P, C E A}(R, N, E, C) & =\sum_{j \in K} C E A_{i}\left(N, c_{. j}, P_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{j \in M} \min \left\{\lambda_{j}, t_{i j}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

We illustrate this rule in the following example.

Example 2 Let $N=\{1,2\}, M=\{1,2,3\}$, and

$$
t=\left(\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 1 & 95
\end{array}\right)
$$

First stage.

$$
P\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)=(0.06,0.06,2.88)
$$

Second Stage. Given $j \in\{1,2\}, \lambda_{j}=0.03$ and

$$
C E A\left(N, c_{. j}, P_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=(0.03,0.03)
$$

Given $j=3, \lambda_{j}=1.88$ and

$$
C E A\left(N, c_{. j}, P_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=(1,1.88)
$$

Then,

$$
R^{P, C E A}(R, N, E, C)=(1.06,1.94)
$$

# 4.2 Results for families of indices 

We now move from the three specific indices considered above to the two families of indices encompassing pairs of them.

We consider first the probabilistic indices (encompassing the user-centric and Shapley indices). As the next result states, they are connected to two-stage rules where the constrained equal awards rule is used in the first stage.

To present the result, we need some notation first. Let $\rho$ be a probabilistic system. For each $j \in M$ we can define the claims rule $\rho^{j}$ induced by the probabilistic system $\rho$ as follows. For each $(N, c, E) \in \mathcal{C}$, and each $i \in N$, we define $\rho_{i}^{j}(N, c, E)=\rho_{i}(j, c) E$.

We say that a claims rule $R$ satisfies non-negativity and dummy if for each $(N, c, E) \in \mathcal{C}$ and each $i \in N, R_{i}(N, c, E) \geq 0$ and $R_{i}(N, c, E)=0$ when $c_{i}=0$.

Let $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ be a streaming problem and $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ be the associated (multiissue) claims problem. We define the set of rewards induced by probabilistic indices as

$$
R P I(N, M, t)=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: x=I^{\rho}(N, M, t) \text { for some probabilistic index } I^{\rho}\right\}
$$

We define the set of allocations induced by two-stage rules $R^{\psi, \phi}$ where $\psi=C E A$ and, for each $j \in K, \phi^{j}$ is a claims rule that satisfies non-negativity and dummy, as

$$
C N D(N, K, c, E)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: x=R^{C E A, \phi}(N, K, c, E) \\
\text { where for each } j \in K, \phi^{j} \text { satisfies non-negativity and dummy }
\end{array}\right\}
$$

Theorem 2 Let $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ be a streaming problem and $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ be the associated (multi-issue) claims problem. Then, the following statements hold:

- For each probabilistic index $I^{\rho}, I^{\rho}(N, M, t)=R^{C E A, \rho}(N, K, c, E)$ where $\rho=\left\{\rho^{j}\right\}_{j \in K}$.
- $\operatorname{RPI}(N, M, t)=C N D(N, K, c, E)$.

Proof. For the first item, given $i \in N$, we compute $R_{i}^{C E A, \rho}(N, K, c, E)$.
First stage. We know from the proof of Theorem 1 that for each $j \in K, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)=1$. Second stage.

$$
\rho_{i}^{j}\left(N, c_{. j}, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=\rho_{i}\left(j, c_{. j}\right)
$$

Thus, for each $i \in N$,

$$
R_{i}^{C E A, \rho}(N, K, c, E)=\sum_{j \in K} \rho_{i}\left(j, c_{. j}\right)=\sum_{j \in M} \rho_{i}\left(j, t_{. j}\right)=I_{i}^{\rho}(N, M, t)
$$

This proves the first item. Note that it also proves one implication of the second item, i.e., $\operatorname{RPI}(N, M, t) \subseteq C N D(N, K, c, E)$.

We now prove the second implication, i.e., $C N D(N, K, c, E) \subseteq R P I(N, M, t)$. Let $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ be such that $x=R^{C E A, \phi}(N, K, c, E)$ where for each $j \in K, \phi^{j}$ satisfies non-negativity and dummy. We now define the probability system $\rho: \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}$ as follows. For each $j \in \mathbb{M}$ and each $y \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}$,

$$
\rho_{i}(j, y)=\phi_{i}^{j}(N, y, 1)
$$

As $\phi^{j}$ is a claims rule that satisfies non negativity and dummy, we have that $0 \leq \rho_{i}(j, y)$, $\rho_{i}(j, y)=0$ when $y_{i}=0$, and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \rho_{i}(j, y)=1$. Thus, $\rho$ is a probabilistic system. Now,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{i}^{\rho}(N, M, t) & =\sum_{j \in M} \rho_{i}\left(j, t_{. j}\right)=\sum_{j \in M} \phi_{i}^{j}\left(N, t_{. j}, 1\right)=\sum_{j \in K} \phi_{i}^{j}\left(N, c_{. j}, C E A_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right) \\
& =R_{i}^{C E A, \phi}(N, K, c, E)=x_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

The second item of Theorem 2 says that the family of probabilistic indices induces the same rewards as the family of two-stage rules with the constrained equal awards rule in the first stage (any claims rule satisfying non-negativity and dummy can be used for the second stage).

We now shift our focus to the family of weighted (rather than probabilistic) indices (which encompass the pro-rata and user-centric indices).

We first consider the sub-family made of weighted indices where the weight depends only on the user (and not on the streams). Formally, given a weighted index $I^{w}$ we say that $I^{w}$ is a user-weighted index if for each $j \in M$ and each pair $x, x^{\prime} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}, w(j, x)=w\left(j, x^{\prime}\right)$. Thus, for each $j \in M$, we can define $w_{j}=w(j, x)$ with $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}$.

We show next that each user-weighted index is associated with a two-stage rule where in the first stage we consider a weighted proportional rule and in the second stage we consider the (unweighted) proportional rule. Besides, we also show that the allocations induced by the rewards associated with user-weighted indices coincide with the allocations induced by twostage rules where a rule satisfying positivity is used in the first stage, and the proportional rule is used in the second stage.

Formally, we say that a claims rule $R$ satisfies positivity if, for each $(N, c, E) \in \mathcal{C}$ and each $i \in N$ such that $c_{i}>0, R_{i}(N, c, E)>0$.

Let $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ be a streaming problem and $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ be the associated (multiissue) claims problem. We define the set of rewards induced by user-weighted indices as

$$
U W I(N, M, t)=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: x=R^{I^{w}}(N, M, t) \text { for some user-weighted index } I^{w}\right\}
$$

We define the set of allocations induced by two-stage rules $R^{\psi, \phi}$ where $\psi$ is a rule satisfying positivity and $\phi^{j}=P$ for each $j \in M$ as

$$
P P(N, K, c, E)=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: x=R^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, c, E) \text { where } \psi \text { is a rule satisfying positivity } \\
\text { and for each } j \in K, \phi^{j}=P
\end{array}\right\}
$$

Theorem 3 Let $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ be a streaming problem and $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ be the associated (multi-issue) claims problem. Then, the following statements hold:

- For each user-weighted index $I^{w}, R^{I^{w}}(N, M, t)=R^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, c, E)$ where $\psi=P^{w}$ (the weighted proportional rule given by $\left(w_{j}\right)_{j \in M}$ ) and $\phi^{j}=P$ for each $j \in M$.
- $U W I(N, M, t)=P P(N, K, c, E)$.

Proof. For the first item, given $i \in N$, we compute $R_{i}^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, c, E)$ where $\psi=P^{w}$ and for each $j \in M, \phi^{j}=P$.

First stage. For each $j \in K$,

$$
P_{j}^{w}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)=\frac{w_{j} T^{j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in K} w_{j^{\prime}} T^{j}} m
$$

Second stage.

$$
P_{j}^{j}\left(N, c_{, j}, P_{j}^{w}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=\frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}} \frac{w_{j} T^{j}}{\sum_{j^{\prime} \in K} w_{j^{\prime}} T^{j}} m
$$

Thus, for each $i \in N$,

$$
R_{i}^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, c, E)=\sum_{j \in K} P_{i}^{j}\left(N, c_{, j}, P_{j}^{w}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=\frac{\sum_{j \in M} w_{j} t_{i j}}{\sum_{j \in M} w_{j} T^{j}} m
$$

Now,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{j \in M} w_{j} t_{i j}=\sum_{j \in M} w\left(j, t_{, j}\right) t_{i j}, \text { and } \\
& \sum_{j \in M} w_{j} T^{j}=\sum_{j \in M} w_{j}\left(\sum_{i \in N} t_{i j}\right)=\sum_{i \in N}\left(\sum_{j \in M} w_{j} t_{i j}\right)=\sum_{i \in N}\left(\sum_{j \in M} w\left(j, t_{, j}\right) t_{i j}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We thus deduce that $R_{i}^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, c, E)=R_{i}^{I^{w}}(N, M, t)$, which proves the first item, as well as one implication of the second item, i.e., $U W I(N, M, t) \subseteq P P(N, K, c, E)$.

We now prove the other implication, i.e., that $P P(N, K, c, E) \subseteq U W I(N, M, t)$. Let $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ be such that $x=R^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, c, E)$ where $\psi$ is a rule satisfying positivity, and for each $j \in K$, $\phi^{j}=P$. We now define the weight system $\omega: \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ as follows. Given $j \in \mathbb{M}$ and $y \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}$, we define

$$
w(j, y)=\frac{\psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right)}{T^{j}}
$$

As $\psi$ is a rule satisfying positivity and $T^{j}>0$ for all $j \in M$, we have that $w(j, y)>0$. As $w$ does not depend on $y$, we conclude that $w$ is a user-weighted system.

Let $i \in N$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{i}^{I^{w}}(N, M, t) & =\frac{\sum_{j \in M} w\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i j}}{\sum_{i \in N}\left(\sum_{j \in M} w\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i j}\right)} m=\frac{\sum_{j \in M} \frac{\psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right)}{T^{j}} t_{i j}}{\sum_{i \in N}\left(\sum_{j \in M} \frac{\psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right)}{T^{j}} t_{i j}\right)} m \\
& =\sum_{j \in M} \frac{\frac{\psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right)}{T^{j}} t_{i j}}{\sum_{j \in M} \frac{\psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right)}{T^{j}}\left(\sum_{i \in N} t_{i j}\right)} m=\sum_{j \in M} \frac{\psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right)}{\sum_{j \in M} \psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right)} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}} m \\
& =\sum_{j \in M} \psi_{j}\left(M,\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in M}, m\right) \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}}=\sum_{j \in M} \psi_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right) \frac{c_{i j}}{c_{j}^{K}} \\
& =\sum_{j \in K} P_{i}^{j}\left(N, c_{. j}, \psi_{j}\left(K, c^{K}, E\right)\right)=R_{i}^{\psi, \phi}(N, K, c, E)=x_{i} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The second item of Theorem 3 says that the family of user-weighted indices induces the same rewards as the family of two-stage rules where we use the proportional rule in the second stage (any claims rule satisfying positivity can be used for the first stage).

We conclude considering another subfamily of weighted indices, arising when the weight depends on the user and the total number of streams, but not on how the total streams are divided among artists. Formally, given a weighted index $I^{w}$ we say that $I^{w}$ is a total-streamsweighted index if for all $x, x^{\prime} \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}^{n}$ and all $j \in M$ such that $\sum_{i \in \mathcal{N}} x_{i}=\sum_{i \in \mathcal{N}} x_{i}^{\prime}, w(j, x)=w\left(j, x^{\prime}\right)$. We show that these indices can be seen as specific (multi-issue) weighted proportional rules, rather than two-stage rules.

Theorem 4 Let $(N, M, t) \in \mathcal{P}$ be a streaming problem and $(N, K, c, E) \in \mathcal{M C}$ be the associated (multi-issue) claims problem. Then, for each total-streams-weighted index $I^{\omega}$,

$$
R^{I^{w}}(N, M, t)=P^{w}(N, K, c, E)
$$

where there exists a mapping $w^{*}: \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $w^{*}(j, x)>0$ for each $(j, x) \in \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z}$ and $w_{j}\left(\left(C^{j}\right)_{j \in K}, E\right)=\frac{w^{*}\left(j, C^{j}\right) C^{j}}{\sum_{k \in K} w^{*}\left(k, C^{k}\right) C^{k}}$ for each $j \in M$.

Proof. Given $i \in N$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{i}^{I^{w}}(N, M, t) & =\frac{\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i j}}{\sum_{i^{\prime} \in N} \sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i^{\prime} j}} m=\frac{\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i j}}{\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) \sum_{i^{\prime} \in N} t_{i^{\prime} k}} m \\
& =\frac{\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i j}}{\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) T^{j}} m
\end{aligned}
$$

We define $w^{*}: \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ as follows. Given $(j, x) \in \mathbb{M} \times \mathbb{Z}$, let $t_{. j}^{*}$ be such that $t_{1 j}^{*}=x$ and $t_{i j}^{*}=0$ when $i \neq 1$. We then define $w^{*}(j, x)=w\left(j, t_{. j}^{*}\right)$. Let $i \in N$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{i}^{w}(N, K, c, E) & =\sum_{j \in K} \frac{c_{i j}}{C^{j}} \omega_{j}\left(\left(C^{j}\right)_{j \in K}, E\right) E=\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}} \omega_{j}\left(\left(T^{j}\right)_{j \in K}, m\right) m \\
& =\sum_{j \in M} \frac{t_{i j}}{T^{j}} \frac{\omega^{*}\left(j, T^{j}\right) T^{j}}{\sum_{j \in M} \omega^{*}\left(j, T^{j}\right) T^{j}} m=\frac{\sum_{j \in M} \omega^{*}\left(j, t_{. j}^{*}\right) t_{i j}}{\sum_{j \in M} \omega^{*}\left(j, T^{j}\right) T^{j}} m \\
& =\frac{\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, t_{. j}\right) t_{i j}}{\sum_{j \in M} \omega\left(j, T^{j}\right) T^{j}} m
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality holds because for each $j \in M, \sum_{i \in N} t_{i j}^{*}=\sum_{i \in N} t_{i j}=T^{j}$.

# 5 Conclusions 

We have explored in this paper the connection between the emerging literature on streaming problems and the well-established literature on (multi-issue) claims problems. We have seen that the most well-known indices to solve streaming problems, and families generalizing them, can be seen as specific rules to solve (multi-issue) claims problems. Our work thus paves the road to consider various known rules for claims problems to solve streaming problems (in new ways that have not been considered so far). Similarly, it opens the possibility to obtain new axiomatic characterizations for the pro-rata index (which can also be seen as the two-stage proportional rule), the user-centric index (which can also be seen as the CEA-proportional two-stage rule) or the Shapley index (which can also be seen as the two-stage CEA rule) in streaming problems, inspired by existing characterizations for claims rules. Finally, it also suggests to consider well-known families of rules for claims problems (e.g., Bergantiños and Vidal-Puga, 2004; Moreno-Ternero, 2011; van den Brink and Moreno-Ternero, 2017) to solve streaming problems.

We conclude mentioning that the game-theoretical approach is another indirect way of solving streaming problems. There is a long tradition in economics and operations research of analyzing problems involving agents' cooperation with a game-theoretical approach. Classical instances are airport problems (e.g., Littlechild and Owen, 1973), bankruptcy problems from the Talmud (e.g., Aumann and Maschler, 1985) or cost-allocation problems (e.g., Tijs and Driessen, 1986). More recent instances are the allocation of benefits of horizontal cooperation (e.g., Lozano et al., 2013), the sharing of fish aggregating devices (e.g., Bergantiños et al., 2023) or even explainable artificial intelligence (e.g., Borgonovo et al., 2024). In our case here, this (game-theoretical) approach amounts to associate each streaming problem with a cooperative TU-game (rather than with a claims problems) in which the worth of each coalition of artists is determined by the amount paid by users that are only streaming those artists. The standard option is to take a pessimistic stance in which only users that exclusively streamed artists in a given coalition will count for the worth (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2025). Alternatively, one could consider an optimistic stance, in which all users that streamed some artist in the coalition count (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2024). It turns out that the Shapley value of both (pessimistic and optimistic) games would coincide, giving rise to the Shapley index considered in this paper (e.g., Bergantiños and Moreno-Ternero, 2024). Schlicher et al. (2024) associate another cooperative game to a streaming problem and study the core.

abstract:
We study the problem of allocating the revenues raised via paid subscriptions
to music streaming platforms among participating artists. We show that the main
methods to solve streaming problems (pro-rata, user-centric and families
generalizing them) can be seen as specific (well-known) rules to solve
(multi-issue) claims problems. Our results permit to provide strong links
between the well-established literature on claims problems and the emerging
literature on streaming problems.
